The Data Protection Commission (DPC) is an independent statutory body established under the Data Protection Act, 2012 (Act 843) to protect the privacy of the individual and personal data by regulating the processing of personal information. 

"The Data Protection Act, 2012 (Act 843) sets out the rules and principles governing the collection, use, disclosure and care of your personal data or information by a data controller or processor. It recognises a person's right (data subject rights) to protect their personal data or information by mandating a data controller or processor to process (collect, use, disclose, erase, etc) such personal data or information in accordance with the individual's rights. The Act also established the Data Protection Commission as an independent statutory body to ensure and enforce compliance. "

The framework is very comprehensive and provides the guideline for the protection of personal data. The Act empowers data subjects with the rights of choice, access, consent, correction of personal data about the data subjects as well as a means of redress. This Act outlines various responsibilities for data controllers such  prohibition to purchase, obtain or disclose personal data and prohibition of sale of personal data.


The Commission also has a web portal where a new user can register, an old user can login and renew and also search for existing information.

Ghana has a draft Ghana Open Data Sharing Policy. This is yet to be passed as law. If this is passed, it will make data sharing easy for government agencies and other stakeholders in the open data ecosystem. This draft policy clearly mandates MMDAs to publish data on the open data portal and also update it regularly. The policy clearly defines what open data is, all open data by government will be published under the most recent version of the Open Data Commons Attribution license, in a machine readable format (CSV, Jason, XML, geoJSON and KML), with the prescribed update cycle and lastly the data must be described as per the guidelines of the Data Catalogue Vocabulary (DCAT).

Nevertheless, various government agencies have internal policies on generating and publishing open data. This includes the open data policy of the Ghana Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative and The digital financial services policy of Ministry of Finance.
